ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This question very much depends on what you write your thesis on. However, I think most students will learn about managing their time over long projects, and what the work of an academic is actually like. Also, about the methods specific to your thesis, and the subject material you are writing about.

This work was mostly self-directed research. It was cool to do research on a topic of interest and an interesting challenge to synthesize the E, P, and E of the work we've done throughout our time here.
Its the senior essay, I learned how to write a thesis by doing it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed the wide discretion I had to write my thesis as I wanted to. I think there was support from my advisor and from the DUS, which was very helpful, but I appreciated that at the end of the day, the essay was my own. I also really like how broad the requirements of the thesis are, as they allowed me to write about topics I was interested in without worrying too much about ticking boxes. I feel I learned a lot about how to do long form academic work, the subject material of my thesis, and how to manage my time independently.

It's pretty self-directed, so it is what you make of it. Each person's experience will differ. I got the exact right combination of support and freedom with this paper. I never felt forced to do anything I didn't want to or to jump through academic hoops for bureaucratic or silly reasons, but I did feel like my questions could all be answered easily and without hassle.
Lower the page count so a year-long thesis is more in line with other majors.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this to other students. I know you have to write a thesis regardless, but I found the experience really rewarding. Particularly if you have any interest in pursuing academia or research, it's a great way to get a feel for it and see if you actually like it. Additionally, it was really nice to  use the skills I've acquired throughout the major and my time at Yale and produce something. Also, I appreciated writing the thesis in the standalone EP&E 491, as then I didn't have to worry about class readings or anything like that and could spend all my time researching and writing the paper.

You're required to do this so it doesn't matter if I'd recommend it! But yes I do! Just make sure you get a good advisor who believes in you. I think that's far more important than even subject matter expertise. And get a second reader who also likes you! It makes the whole experience so much more positive and exciting, rather than stressful.

And get started early -- just for your own benefit, you don't want to give short shrift to this essay, since it's a culmination of all your undergrad work and also a likely candidate for a writing sample in your future.
